BA Single Honours: Childhood and Youth Degrees

column1: <tr> <td> <table width="100%" border="1" align="left" cellpadding="2" cellspacing="0" class="bodytext"><tr class="infopanel">
BA Single Honours: Childhood and Youth Degrees
Email a friend information about this course

This degree programme provides opportunities to explore a range of areas relating to children and youth. It will give you an academic grounding for understanding issues relevant to working with children and adolescents, from birth to eighteen.

This is a multidisciplinary course drawing on psychology, sociology and social policy, the law, health and sport, the humanities and cultural studies. ChildrenÂs lives and experiences will be examined from different perspectives through a variety of themes.

Central to the programme are the needs, rights and quality of life of children and adolescents, and the interaction of young people with communities and society. The programme will provide scope to pursue particular areas of interest, such as child development, social welfare of the young, nutrition and health, representations of children and youth in literature, past childhoods, diversity including special needs and youth culture.
Why Childhood and Youth at Leeds Trinity?
• Unique mix of subject areas to give you considerable insight into the psychological, social, legal, physical and cultural dimensions of childhood and youth, from birth to eighteen.
• Friendly teaching staff with regular contact with tutors to help you in your studies.
• Periods of working in organisational contexts involving children and young people.
What jobs do Childhood and Youth graduates get?

The course can help prepare you for a career in education, health and social care, the youth sector, and other public and voluntary services, where there is a need for understanding of, and communication with,
Childhood and Youth Degree - Typical Content:

• Introduction to Child Development
  • Childhood, Society and Social Policy
  • Health and Young People
  • Changing Perceptions of Childhood and Adolescence
  • Making Sense of Culture
  • Professional Development & Placement 1

• Language and Thinking in the School Years
  • Young People and The Law

• Youth, Leisure and Lifestyle
  • ÂSweeps and Rabbit-holesÂ
  • Introduction to Evidence-based Learning
  • Professional Development & Placement 2

• Childhood and Youth in Social Context
  • Child and Youth Justice
  • Research Project or Dissertation
  • Young People and Diversity
  • Sport and Physical Activity with Young People
  • Promoting Young PeopleÂs Health
  • ÂGardens, Streets and PlaygroundsÂ

Lectures are combined with a wide range of teaching support in the form of tutorials, seminars, workshops, project work and case studies.

Assessment is by a combination of methods including essays, tutorials, seminars and examinations. Your performance in professional attachments will also be assessed as an integral part of the degree.

Professional work placements are a key part of the programme providing practical experience of working in an organisation, for example, health & social care, health promotion and education. Your work placement will enable you to apply the skills you have gained in academic study to actual work situations.

You will be required to undertake a police check (an enhanced disclosure from the Criminal Records Bureau) prior to starting a placement working with young people.
